content.description: This route moves through a small, awkward roof by way of an odd ramp into highly fractured rock along a crack system with many options for feet and hands. The gear on this route is solid and not too spaced but makes for a heady lead due to the nature of the fracturing and wedged blocks.
content.protection: Fingers to hands, doubles of 0.5 & 0.75 are useful, 1 bolt, and a bolted anchor.
content.location: It ascends the centrally located arete through fractured blocks and pillars passing a single bolt as it moves slightly out and right to a three bolt anchor.

content.description: This route ascends a brief but pumpy, minute, left-trending seam over a bulge before easing up for some 25 feet of good, vertical, rail pulling. The crux is moving through the first two bolts finding good positive edges and rails within the fracture.
content.location: This route is located in the middle of the wall on a slightly shorter section and ascends a very thin, left-trending seam within a black streak.

content.protection: A medium C3 for the start and 3 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
It is left of the dirty corner that borders

Rick Ross Big Bosch

and shares anchors with

No Gear Left Behind

.

content.description:
This route shares the last bolt and chains with "

Ellie's Route

" to the left. Start in a coner with a tips seem about 15 feet left of the start of "

Ellie's Route

." Make a move up to the thin fingers locker with the help of a few positive edges, and reach left to clip the first bolt. Reach way left to a good hold atop the sloping ramp, readjust, find the left hand sidepull, and clip the 2nd bolt. Now slap a hand high to the square ledge, and pull up into the finger crack and plug. From here, traverse left to join "

Ellie's Route

."
content.protection: 3 bolts and a 0.5 / baggy fingers piece to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Start in a corner with a tips seam about 15 feet left of the start of "

Ellie's Route

" just under the large, flat ledge at mid-height.

content.description: This route moves through two bolts, the second protecting a small roof, before entering a thin fracture on the face with good, albeit finicky gear. This route is named not for the necessity of the abundance of gear but rather in reference to the cowardice of the first ascensionist who chose to bring and place all of the gear remotely possible despite the brevity of the climb....
content.protection: A few C3s or equivalent and a thin hand piece, two bolts, and a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Look for  a bolt just under a left-trending, hand-sized ledge leading to a small roof on top of which is a second bolt. Above the two bolts is a thin seam that eventually must be abandoned to head right towards the anchors.

content.description:
This route shares anchors with

Basalt Assault

to the left and climbs the obvious fingers corner to the right. It can be climbed using the first two bolts of

Basalt Assault

and then breaking right into the corner or by climbing direct placing tricky pro on less solid rock. After pulling through the corner, a large ledge provides a hands free rest from which you can clip the last bolt of

Basalt Assault

before an easy stretch to the anchors.
content.protection: Fingers and smaller, 1 bolt, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the obvious fingers corner that starts mid way up the wall at about the center.  A large spruce crowds the base of the wall just to the right.

climbs.name: Gotta Have Balls, Gotta Have Nuts

content.description: After an easy jaunt up to the ledge, clip the first bolt and move up and right on positive if fleeting holds. Plug some gear at your waist, and move into the fractured system that encompasses the face. A 0.3 BD can be placed in a small, vertical pod from a good stance easing the mind a bit when contemplating the accompanying gear. Using rails, crimps, and sidepulls, move yourself into position under the vertical seam where you will place your final pro. This is the mental crux of the climb as it is protected with the little stuff (C3s, ballnuts, etc...). Pull over the bulge and slightly left, and you're there. This is a fun route with small gear and fun movement.
content.protection: Tight fingers and smaller (several ballnuts and C3s with a BD 0.3 as the largest piece made for the original rack), 1 bolt, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the first route encountered, and it shares anchors with

Cool Corner

. A spruce tree just set back from the base makes for a great shady belay.

content.description: Start on the left side of a refrigerator-ish-sized pillar making a move to jugs. Clip your first bolt from the jug before the compression heavy crux standing up to good feet and hands. Plug some gear on easy terrain before the last bolt. Don't miss the sweet finger pocket to clip from!  Move up through some more demanding terrain to a hand jam and the chains.
content.protection: Two bolts, a fingers piece, a #2 BD, and a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This climb begins on top of a scramble as the cliff begins to shorten as it moves west. It is just left of the massive flat top block at mid-height to the left of "

Back To School

."

content.description: Cool Corner shares anchors and climbs the corner breaking right at the finish. Conquer the chossy ledge to reach the start of the corner ignoring the staring bolt for the route next door. Plug a finger-sized piece at your chest to keep you from bouncing off the ledge if you blow the first clip. Move through the corner clipping 3 bolts to the crux pulling through to a massive ledge that serves as a jug. Clip your last bolt, and use the sloping ledge to move right to the anchors.
content.protection: A finger-sized piece is optional before the first bolt, 4 bolts, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the second route you encounter when approaching from the east and is next to a large spruce set back approximately 10 feet from the wall. The corner climbs left of

Gotta Have Balls, Gotta Have Nuts

, which climbs the minutely fractured face right of the anchors.

content.description:
This is the sporty alternate ending to the pure gear line

Big Blocky

. Break right after stepping into the crack above the detached block to clip two bolts on your way to the chains.
content.protection: Fists to hands, two bolts, and a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Start the same as

Big Blocky

, and break right for the bolted face.

content.description:
This route starts with a tricky mantel to set up under an impeding roof. Slot a finger-size piece (maybe a BD 0.4), and pull over the bulge to a decent stance to clip your third bolt. From there, work your way up and right on thin rails and into pockets to the anchors shared with "

Here's Johnny

."
content.protection: 5 bolts, a fingers-size piece to supplement pulling the roof, and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This route climbs through the obvious roof and blank looking face just to the left of a fingers-size corner. It is left of the large spruce that splits this wall in half in the beta photo.

content.description: Start in the vesicled rock, and climb quickly into a crack system with a large ledge to the right at about 10 to 15 feet. From there, you can plug gear in the tight finger (tips) crack recessed in an obtuse corner. Pull up to some ledges on the face left and rattly fingers as you tunnel back under a roof. Pull the roof to a ledge and anchors.
content.location:
This is just left of "

No Gear Left Behind

." It is the last climb moving west before a section of wall that is very bushy and broken.

content.description: This route moves up a brief offwidth through a small bulge on vessicled rock onto a large, detached block. From here, the crack goes from fists to thin hands with many features for a reprieve from jamming.
content.protection: Fists to thin hands.  A number 5 or even 6 may fit down low for added comfort.
content.location: This route is tall and starts from a grassy bench to the right of the large spruce tree that divides the wall. Two bolts are visible on the face below the chains belonging to the sporty variation.

content.description: This route climbs through a tricky crux in a beautiful, fractured panel before a relaxed finish on lower angle rock with wide pro. While it is all gear protected, this route feels sporty and thoughtful with few jams.
content.protection: Baggy fingers to a number six if you want it and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: The route starts in vesicled rock before pulling onto a solid ledge below a fractured panel. The wide crack on low angle rock leading to the only nearby anchors give it away.
